Detailed Description

Represents a filesystem path.

The path this represents does not necessarily exists, nor does it have to be valid for the current operating system.

However this object is intended to provided platform independent methods for dealing with file system paths.

Example Usage

Constructor & Destructor Documentation

chaos::io::sys::Path::Path ( )

Default constructor.

Creates a new empty Path.

chaos::io::sys::Path::Path ( const std::vector< chaos::str::UTF8String > &  components)

Component constructor.

Creates a new Path from the given std::vector of components.

For example the native Linux path:

path/to/file.txt

Would be passed to this constructor like so:

std::vector< chaos::str::UTF8String > components;
components.push_back( "path" );
components.push_back( "to" );
components.push_back( "file.txt" );
chaos::io::file::Path p( components );
chaos::io::sys::Path::Path ( const chaos::str::UTF8String &  string_path)

Attempts to create a Path object from the given single string using the current operating system's path rules.

Note
This constructor method should be avoided where possible. Instead constructing paths using the << operator or join() function is recommended.

On Unix systems this will split the given string into components using the "/" symbol. Likewise on Windows systems the "\" symbol will be used.

chaos::io::sys::Path::Path ( const Path &  other)

Copy constructor.

Creates a new Path by copying the contents of the provided Path.

Whether the paths are equal.
bool chaos::io::sys::Path::operator< ( const Path &  other) const

Less than operator.

Compares whether this Path is considered less than the other given Path.

Note
This operator is primarily supplied so Path objects can be stored in a std::map.

Less than is defined by the number of components in a Path, and if two paths have the same number of components then this resorts to a UTF8String less than comparison on each component until a mismatch is found.

Parameters
otherPath to compare this against.
Returns
Whether this Path is less than the other.
chaos::str::UTF8String& chaos::io::sys::Path::operator[] ( size_t  index)

chaos::ex::IndexOutOfBoundsErrorIf the provided index is out of bounds of the number of components in this Path.

Returns a const reference to the component of this Path at the given index.

Exceptions
chaos::ex::IndexOutOfBoundsErrorIf the provided index is out of bounds of the number of components in this Path.
Path chaos::io::sys::Path::operator+ ( const Path &  other) const

Addition operator.

Creates a new Path by extending the components of this Path with the components of the other given Path.

Example usage:

chaos::io::file::Path p1;
p1 << "two" << "part";
chaos::io::file::Path p2;
p2 << "path" << "to" << "file.txt";
chaos::io::file::Path p3 = p1 + p2;
// p3 contains [ "two", "part", "path", "to", "file.txt" ]
const Path& chaos::io::sys::Path::operator+= ( const Path &  other)

Compound addition operator.

Extends this Path with the components of the other given Path.

Example usage:

chaos::io::file::Path p1;
p1 << "two" << "part";
chaos::io::file::Path p2;
p2 << "path" << "to" << "file.txt";
p1 += p2;
// p1 contains [ "two", "part", "path", "to", "file.txt" ]
Path& chaos::io::sys::Path::operator<< ( const chaos::str::UTF8String &  component)

Join operator.

Appends a new component to end of this path. This is the same as using the join() function.

Example usage:

chaos::io::file::Path p;
p << "path" << "to" << "file.txt";
// p now contains [ "path", "to", "file" ]
Parameters
componentString to be appended to the end of this Path as a component.
Returns
Reference to this Path after the join has taken place.
Path& chaos::io::sys::Path::join ( const chaos::str::UTF8String &  component)

Appends a new component to the end of this Path.

Since this returns a non-const reference to this Path, these functions can be chained.

Example usage:

chaos::io::file::Path p;
p.join( "path" ).join( "to" ).join( "file.txt" );
// p now contains [ "path", "to", "file" ]
Parameters
componentchaos::str::UTF8String to be appended to the end of this Path as a component.
Returns
Reference to this Path after the join has taken place.
void chaos::io::sys::Path::insert ( size_t  index,
const chaos::str::UTF8String &  component 
)

Inserts the component at the given index in this Path.

If the index is less than the length of the string, the component currently at the index and all following components will be shuffled along one position.

If the index is equal to the current number of components in this Path, this function is the same as calling join().

If the index is greater than the number of components in this Path, an exception will be thrown.

Example usage:

chaos::io::file::Path p;
p << "path" << "file.txt";
p.insert( 1, "to" );
// p now contains [ "path", "to", "file.txt" ]
Exceptions
chaos::ex::IndexOutOfBoundsErrorIf the provided index is greater than the number of components currently in this Path.
Parameters
indexPosition to insert the new component at.
componentchaos::str::UTF8String representing the new component to be inserted.
void chaos::io::sys::Path::clear ( )

Reverts this Path to be an empty path.

Clears any current components this Path has.

void chaos::io::sys::Path::remove ( size_t  index)

Removes the component from this Path at the given index.

Exceptions
chaos::ex::IndexOutOfBoundsErrorIf the provided index is out of bounds of the number of components in this Path.
Parameters
indexThe index of the component to remove from this path.
chaos::str::UTF8String chaos::io::sys::Path::to_native ( ) const

Returns the chaos::str::UTF8String representation of this Path for the current operating system.

Example usage:

chaos::io::file::Path p;
p << "path" << "to" << "file.txt";
chaos::str::UTF8String s = p.to_native();
// on Unix systems s will be "path/to/file.txt"
// on Windows systems s will be "path\to\file.txt"
chaos::str::UTF8String chaos::io::sys::Path::to_unix ( ) const

Returns the chaos::str::UTF8String representation of this Path for Unix based operating systems.

Example usage:

chaos::io::file::Path p;
p << "path" << "to" << "file.txt";
chaos::str::UTF8String s = p.to_unix();
// s is "path/to/file.txt"
chaos::str::UTF8String chaos::io::sys::Path::to_windows ( ) const

Returns the chaos::str::UTF8String representation of this Path for Windows based operating systems.

Example usage:

chaos::io::file::Path p;
p << "path" << "to" << "file.txt";
chaos::str::UTF8String s = p.to_windows();
// s is "path\to\file.txt"
bool chaos::io::sys::Path::exists ( ) const

Returns whether this Path exists.

This function doesn't taken into account the type of the path, the path can point to a directory, file, or symlink for this to evaluate true.

bool chaos::io::sys::Path::is_file ( ) const

Returns whether this path is a valid file.

This function will return false if the path exists but is not a file, or if the path simply does not exist.

bool chaos::io::sys::Path::is_directory ( ) const

Returns whether this path is a valid directory.

This function will return false if the path exists but is not a directory, or if the path simply does not exist.

bool chaos::io::sys::Path::is_symlink ( ) const

Returns whether this path is a valid symbolic link.

This function will return false if the path exists but is not a symbolic link, or if the path simply does not exist.

size_t chaos::io::sys::Path::get_length ( )

Returns the number of components in this path.

Example usage:

chaos::io::file::Path p;
p << "path" << "to" << "file.txt";
p.get_length(); // returns: 3
const std::vector< chaos::str::UTF8String >& chaos::io::sys::Path::get_components ( ) const

Returns the individual components which make up this path.

For example the native Linux path:

path/to/file.txt

Stored correctly in a Path object:

chaos::io::file::Path path;
path << "path" << "to" << "file.txt";

Would contain the components:

[ "path", "to", "file.txt" ]
chaos::str::UTF8String chaos::io::sys::Path::get_extension ( ) const

Returns the file extension of the leaf component of this Path.

Example usage:

chaos::io::file::Path p;
p << "path" << "to" << "file.txt";
chaos::str::UTF8String ext = p.get_extension();
// ext is "txt"
